utterances: Yes, but that has not been verified, and there have been questions brought up as to whether somebody can send an SMS message from 30,000 or 34,000 feet altitude.
How are people responding to this news on the ground?
Well, people are really devastated and shocked.
There's also been an outcry against the airline, because people felt that the airline didn't respond in a timely manner.
They hadn't made known the passenger list to the relatives as of 5:30 PM yesterday, and that was after Cypriot Transport Minister Haris Thrassou imposed a deadline for them to do so.

So there was really pretty heart-wrenching scenes at Larnaca Airport with relatives waiting there and waiting to find out about their loved ones and, you know, becoming a little bit aggressive with airline personnel.
Thanks very much.
We've been talking to Penny Gourntis of the Athens News Agency about the crash of a jetliner in Greece.
This is NPR News.
Now to Iraq.
The Iraqi parliament broke a weeks-long stalemate today and passed three pieces of legislation.
Two of them appear to make progress toward political benchmarks set by the Bush administration.
The measure is passed after a bitter and angry debate in which some lawmakers called for the parliament to be dissolved.
NPR's Peter Kenyon has more from Baghdad.
The American decision to send five additional brigades to Iraq a year ago, largely to pacify the capital, was intended to create the conditions for desperately needed political progress in Iraq.

But for a long time it seemed that the efforts of 30,000 extra American troops and their Iraqi counterparts had simply allowed political infighting to blossom among Iraq's Kurdish, Sunni, and Shiite politicians.
Here's how the speaker of parliament Mahmoud Mashhadani described things yesterday after dozens of lawmakers marched out of an especially bitter and nonproductive session.
(Through translator) If we don't pass these three laws, we'll be in a miserable mess and many people will call for the dissolution of the parliament.
I prepared the papers for dissolving the body to be used if we don't enact these laws today.

The legislation in question included the 2008 budget, a limited amnesty law that could lead to the release of thousands of detainees, and a law that would establish powers to be wielded by provincial governments.
The measures did not pass yesterday, but after another ruckus session today, they were finally approved.
Allowing members of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party to return to work.
They represent the most significant political accomplishment in some time.
The highly dysfunctional process, however, revealed the depths of mistrust among the various political blocks.
The Sunnis favored the amnesty law, while the Shiites - eager for more autonomy in the oil-rich south - wanted the Provincial Powers Act to pass.
The Kurds pressed for the budget to include their 17 percent share despite Arab grumbling that population estimate suggests they should only get 13 percent.
Each block was terrified that if one of the others got their law enacted first, they would walk out on the other two.
Sunni politician Saleh al-Mutlaq led his national dialogue movement in a walkout of today's session, saying the Kurds were violating all ethical standards.
Certainly, what they want is that I will keep the prisoners as hostages, and I will not agree about whether to release unless you give me $1.5 bilion.
This is against he principles of every civilized in Arab society.
In the end, compromises were reached on many of the issues.
The Kurds got their 17 percent of the budget this year, but they will a incentives before the next budget allocations are made.
The Sunnis had demanded a firm date for provincial elections and the Provincial Powers Act says they will be held by October.
To get the measures approved in this atmosphere of mistrust, Mashhadani was forced to bundle them together for a single package vote, which some lawmakers complain was unconstitutional.
Afterwards, Mashhadani congratulated his colleagues for their, quote, ""magnificent performance.
(Through translator) This day has truly been a wedding for the Iraqi parliament.
We have proved that the people are one unified block.
Outside the parliament, however, critics not that these measures were hardly the most challenging tasks facing the parliament.
A new oil law and elections law, disarming militias, and other major issues await the lawmakers when they return to work.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Baghdad.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
Twenty years ago this Sunday, Harold Washington, the mayor of Chicago, died at his desk in city hall.
He suffered a massive heart attack shortly after winning a second term in office.
Harold Washington was one of the first black mayors of a major American city, and his death left Chicago reeling.
He was charismatic, loquacious, bigger than life.
And as NPR's Cheryl Corley reports, while his tenure was short, Washington's political philosophy still echoes through politics today.
Harold Washington was a man who loved to read.
And the city's monumental central library is named after him.
I'm standing in the basement lobby, where there are quotes from his inauguration etched on the floor.

Over the next several months, Washington's friends and colleagues will commemorate the 20th anniversary of his death as well as that electrifying night 25 years ago, when he was elected the city's first black mayor.
Unidentified Man #1: You want Harold?
Well, here's Harold.
Russian officials from President Vladimir Putin on down have insisted over and over again that Russia has never had troops or military equipment in Ukraine.
The Kremlin maintains that the conflict is a civil war, pitting Russian-speaking Ukrainians in the East against a fascist junta in Kiev that overthrew the country's legitimate government last year.
Opposition activist Ilya Yashin says the newly-released report shows that it's not a civil war, but a Russian-inspired and supported attempt to divide the country.
(Through interpreter) We're convinced that Putin's policy, the war that Putin unleashed with our fraternal neighboring country, does colossal damage to the national interests of Russia.

Yashin and others who worked on the report say it's based on open-source accounts by journalists, interviews with family members of soldiers who were killed and some anonymous sources in the Russian government.

(Through interpreter) The main conclusion was that we proved the presence of Russian troops in Ukraine and also groups of mercenaries who are recruited, financed and sent to Ukraine to fight Ukrainian government forces.
Yashin says the report shows that at least 220 Russian troops have been killed fighting in Ukraine, and that's a conservative estimate.

He says Russia has poured at least a billion dollars into the military campaign in the East and been forced to spend more than a billion and a half more supporting refugees who were driven from their homes by the fighting.
The report doesn't contain anything that hasn't already been reported by news media or asserted by the United States and its NATO allies.
Just yesterday, NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg accused Russia of violating the cease-fire.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We have seen continued support from Russia to the separatists with heavy weapons, with artillery, with advanced air defense systems, with training and also with forces.
And this is also a blatant violation of the cease-fire.
The authors who completed the Nemtsov report hope it will be read by Russian citizens, who've been subjected to intense propaganda by the government and state-run media.
(Speaking Russian).
That's Mikhail Kasyanov, a former Russian prime minister and co-chairman of the opposition Republican Party of Russia - PARNAS.
He says the report should help Russian citizens compare the information and understand what's going on, despite the propaganda.
The activists also hope their report will serve as a monument to Boris Nemtsov, who was working on it when he was gunned down in central Moscow earlier this year.
Corey Flintoff, NPR News, Moscow.
The Affordable Care Act will require most Americans to have health insurance by the beginning of next year.
The law also sets standards for what that health insurance must cover.
That's potentially a big deal for people with disabilities.
The law could help thousands get therapies they can't get now to help with daily living.
Still, the insurance companies have a lot of discretion as to what to cover, as Colorado Public Radio's Eric Whitney reports.
For 20-year-old film student Bryce Vernon, time with speech language pathologist Jill Tullman is golden.
Now, Bryce, I want to show you this super cool, random button that I think you're going to love.
Vernon has cerebral palsy.
He speaks but only with the aid of a special computer that tracks his eye movements, allowing him to select letters and icons on a screen mounted to his wheelchair.
My name is Bryce Vernon.
I live in Los Angeles.
It's amazing technology.
and Vernon gets a lot more out of it with Tullman's help.
Today, at a special camp for kids who use this technology, she's helping him pre-load several different ways of saying goodbye.
Later, dude, later.
Bye.
I'm out of here.
Isn't that fun?
See you later.
Lots of people like Vernon could benefit from one-on-one time with a therapist to improve their daily living skills.
But it's expensive and not all insurance plans cover it.
The Affordable Care Act is changing that, says health economist Lisa Clemans-Cope, with the Urban Institute.
You're much more likely to find these benefits in a plan after 2014 in the individual market, than you would be today - far more likely.
Far more likely because the health law now requires insurance companies to cover 10 categories of services they didn't have to before.
Some are straightforward like maternity care, drug abuse treatment and preventive care.
But other categories are broader, like the one that includes some services Vernon needs.
And insurance companies can pick and choose which specific therapies they'll cover in each category.

For instance, physical therapy benefits to recover from broken bones can be much more generous than therapies for long-term help for chronic conditions, like speech therapy for kids with cerebral palsy.
Clemans-Cope says some insurers may arrange their benefits in a way that discourages people with expensive conditions from signing up with them.
And she says people who want specific therapies covered are going have to slog through some fine print, to see if they'll actually benefit from the new policies for sale in 2014.
This is a big improvement, but we should emphasize that it's not totally fixed.
And people are really going to have to get help, to help them decide which plans cover the benefits they need.
Whether a person will be able to get the new therapy benefits also depends on where they live.
The level of benefits insurers have to provide in each category is based on a model policy in each state, and some are a lot more generous than others.
